name: Climdex.pcic
tagline: Routines to compute ETCCDI Climdex indices
body:
# What is climdex.pcic?

* `climdex.pcic` is a library for computing the [27 core indices of extreme climate](http://etccdi.pacificclimate.org/list_27_indices.shtml). It was written for the [R statistical programming language](http://www.r-project.org/) by the [Pacific Climate Impacts Consortium](http://pacificclimate.org/).

# Getting Help

## New to programming or to R?

* Read the the [Software Carpentry](http://software-carpentry.org/index.html)  [Programming in R](http://software-carpentry.org/v5/novice/r/index.html) lessons
* Read one of the man [R Manuals](http://cran.r-project.org/manuals.html
).
* Attend an [R Users Group](http://r-users-group.meetup.com/) meeting.

## Looking for code?

* Get the latest [climdex.pcic release from CRAN](http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/climdex.pcic/index.html).
* Install it from the R interpreter
```R
> install.packages('climdex.pcic')
```
* Explore the [development repository](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/).

## Need help using the package?

* Read the manual
```R
    > library(climdex.pcic)
    Loading required package: PCICt
    > ?climdex.pcic
```
* Create a [new issue](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/issues/new) on the [package issue tracker](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/issues) and label it "help wanted"[1].

## Want to contribute?

* To report a bug in pcic.climdex use the [package issue tracker](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/issues) (after you've read the [bug reporting guide](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst#bug-reports)).
* To help with development read through the [contributor's guide](https://github.com/pacificclimate/climdex.pcic/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst).

## Still need help?

* Contact climate@uvic.ca and let us know what we can do.

[1] Please know that the pool of people who can provide support for the package is extremely small and time is limited.  We don't necessarily have the capacity for long, open-ended user support. If you keep your questions short, specific and direct, there's a greater probability that someone will take on the ticket.
